content: The "Savings for Seniors Act of 2017" provides interim protections for the Social Security Trust Fund surplus. The "Savings for Seniors Act of 2017" establishes a Social Security Surplus Protection Account in the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund to transfer social security surplus amounts after each fiscal year. The "Savings for Seniors Act of 2017" establishes a Social Security Surplus Protection Account in the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund to transfer surplus amounts based on tax revenues reported to the Treasury Secretary. The "Savings for Seniors Act of 2017" establishes a Social Security Surplus Protection Account in the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund to transfer surplus amounts based on tax revenues reported to the Treasury Secretary, including self-employment income and tax liabilities under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Savings for Seniors Act of 2017" creates a Social Security Surplus Protection Account in the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund to transfer surplus amounts based on tax revenues reported to the Treasury Secretary. This includes an increase in tax liabilities under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, specifically related to sections 86 and 871(a)(3) for payments from the Trust Fund. The Account balance cannot be invested by the Managing Trustee, and certain provisions do not apply to fiscal years starting after the first fiscal year post-2017 under Federal law. The provision of Federal law post-fiscal year 2017 allows for investment in Trust Fund assets other than US obligations, leading to the transfer of assets to the Treasury's general fund. The law must include a specific clause to meet Social Security Act requirements. SEC. 3. SOCIAL SECURITY INVESTMENT COMMISSION. Established in the executive branch is a Social Security Investment Commission tasked with studying effective investment options for the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund. The Commission must submit recommendations and propose necessary changes by October 1, 2017. The Social Security Investment Commission is composed of 9 members appointed by various officials, with expertise in financial investments and pension plans. Members serve for the life of the Commission, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Social Security Investment Commission is composed of 9 members appointed by officials with expertise in financial investments and pension plans. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, subject to any conditions that applied initially. The Commission meets at least once a month and can convene additional meetings as needed. The functions and powers of the Commission are exercised by a majority vote of a quorum, with three members constituting a quorum for decision-making. The Social Security Investment Commission is composed of 9 members appointed by officials with expertise in financial investments and pension plans. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission meets regularly and functions are carried out by majority vote. Members are compensated at the daily rate of basic pay for level IV of the Executive Schedule and expenses are covered while traveling for Commission duties. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting its report.
